Award.AwardTitle: Graphene-based electrically reconfigurable THz aperture arrays for imaging applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: we aim to design and develop a room temperature graphene-based THz reconfigurable aperture array to realize video-rate THz imaging based on compressive sensing. The proposed device promises an elegant solution to the long standing problem in realizing THz modulation. By electrostatically tuning the Fermi level in a pair of capacitively coupled graphene sheets, the THz transmission intensity can be tuned from > 90% to < 10%, thus pointing ways to fabricate high speed, high resolution, high signal-to-noise ratio and low-cost THz imagers.

Intellectual Merit: THz modulation enabled by intraband transitions in graphene, is another attractive real-world application of graphene besides transparent conductors and frequency multipliers etc. We will also answer questions regarding energy band alignment in graphene/semiconductor heterojunctions, large-area graphene preparation and passivation and electromagnetic interactions in metematerial structures made of graphene and metal.

Broader Impact: The high-speed and efficient THz modulators based on graphene are of immense interest to both the THz and graphene community. Graduate students will be trained in the emergent fields of THz and nanomaterials and they are also an integral element of the designed outreach activities to disseminate the new discoveries to the general audience including undergraduate students, school teachers and K-12 students.

Terahertz (THz) imaging is promising for many important applications in research and technology communities including astronomy, chemistry, biology, medicine, security and defense. To date, THz imaging systems have been successfully demonstrated using two approaches including: (1) single-element imagers acquiring images by mechanical scanning, and (2) array imagers (e.g., focal-plane arrays (FPAs)) consisting of an array of sensor elements. However, the above two approaches either lead to low imaging speed or result in complicated and expensive systems. As compared to the above approaches, THz coded-aperture imaging (CAI) using reconfigurable modulator arrays offers the advantage of both high performance as well as the potential for realizing simple and low-cost systems. In this research, two methods for realizing high performance THz CAI systems have been explored and successfully demonstrated. The first method makes use of electrically reconfigurable graphene THz modulator arrays, while the second method takes advantages of optical THz spatial modulation based on photo-induced free carriers in semiconductors.

 

In order to develop high-performance electrically-reconfigurable aperture arrays, high-speed, room-temperature and efficient THz modulators based on intraband transitions in graphene have been explored. On the basis of the exploration, three different modulator structures, i.e., 2DEG-graphene gate, graphene/graphene pair and graphene/metamaterial combination were fully studied. Measurement results have shown a modulation depth approaching 100%, attenuation less than 15%, and modulation speed of GHz can be achieved as shown in Fig. 1. In addition, graphene THz modulators employing near-field effects have shown >3x performance enhancement (see Fig. 2). The performance of the developed THz modulators including insertion loss and modulation depth were summarized in Fig. 3. The Modulator arrays based on those single devices have been developed experimentally and successfully applied in a THz pixelated imager as seen in Fig. 4. The first method explored using graphene modulator arrays requires complicated prepatterned circuits. CAI using photo-induced reconfigurable masks based on optical THz spatial modulation can overcome this problem, resulting in much simpler systems. Using high-resistivity silicon or germanium, a modulation depth as high as 65 dB and modulation speed approaching 30 kHz have been obtained. Near video-rate THz imaging with 16×16 pixels have also been    demonstrated (see Fig. 5). We expect that the THz imagers developed and demonstrated in this research will find promising applications and be widely deployed.

 

The research supported three Ph.D. students, and five undergraduate students have been involved through summer research programs. Knowledge gleaned from this project has been integrated into the PIs’ graduate and undergraduate courses. Research results have led to a number of journal and conference articles, as well as invited talks at international symposiums. In addition to publications, prototype hardware and software for THz CAI have been established (for general lab usage and other projects) and fully characterized. The THz imaging capabilities developed under this program will be applied in our future research.
